references: In this paper, we address all of the issues outlined above in a unified framework calledÂ HyFL that enables private and robust distributed machine learning at scale. Our framework is based on a novel abstraction that also captures existing regular and hierarchicalÂ FL architectures in aÂ
Briefly, in our framework, FL participants use secret-sharing techniques to securely outsource training data toÂ

that are based onÂ MPC. The participants then might leave and only sporadically return to provide more training data â€“ this makes our framework robust against real-world issues such as drop-outs, requires no interaction between clients, and relieves resource-constraintÂ (mobile or edge) devices from significant workload. The models, which are trained by the clusters withÂ MPC-basedÂ PPML techniques, are then aggregated across all training clusters using one or multiple levels of distributed aggregators. For secure distributed aggregation, we again utilizeÂ MPC.
Note that after aggregation, models are not publicly released but in secret-shared form handed back to training clusters for the next training iteration. After training is completed, known secure inference protocols can be used to allow private queriesÂ
in a controlledÂ (potentially rate-limited) way. This architecture design addresses issuesÂ P1 andÂ P3 by relying on a distributed instead of single aggregator and notably achievesÂ
due to a novel combination ofÂ FL withÂ PPML techniques.

We observe that a neat property of our framework is the strictly limited attack surface: similar toÂ PPML, malicious participants are restricted to weaker data-poisoning attacks as there is no possibility to access and manipulate the model itself. However, while defending against data poisoning inÂ PPML is highly non-trivial, we show experimentally that state-of-the-art data-poisoning attacks in the suggested hierarchical configuration are less effective than in plainÂ FL. Furthermore, we implement and evaluate different robust aggregation schemes to further mitigate the effect of such attacks; for this, we additionally propose new heuristics that improve the efficiency for the correspondingÂ MPC implementation. Specifically, we propose a lightweight variant of the
defense, for our setting with only data-poisoning attacks. This addresses issueÂ P2.
Finally, we implement allÂ HyFL components in an open-source PyTorch-basedÂ FL framework that utilizesÂ Metaâ€™s CrypTen frameworkÂ

for instantiatingÂ MPC, which we also extend for our use case with several general-purpose functionalities like optimized oblivious sorting algorithms.
We then evaluate the performance when training neural networks for standard image classification tasks in realistic network settings and usingÂ GPU-acceleratedÂ AWS EC2 instances.
This way, we show that the computation and communication overhead induced by incorporating secure computation techniques is feasible even for large-scale deployments.
For example, one round of trainingÂ LeNet on theÂ MNIST dataset forÂ 5 epochs with batch sizeÂ 80 takes less thanÂ 5 minutes for a cluster withÂ 10 participants, and global aggregation amongÂ 10 clusters happens in less thanÂ 1 second.
Moreover, we find that the impact ofÂ MPC-induced inaccuracies is less thanÂ 0.1%, and models trained withÂ HyFL converge significantly faster than in plainÂ FL.
In summary, we provide the following contributions:

New scalableÂ (hierarchical)Â FL framework calledÂ HyFL that achieves complete model privacy, supports resource-limited mobile or edge devices, and significantly limits the attack surface for malicious participants to data poisoning attacks.
Analysis of data-poisoning attacks in hierarchical setting with new efficiency improvements for secure robust aggregation.
Open-source implementation and evaluation ofÂ HyFL on standard image classification tasks.
, we furthermore clarify howÂ HyFL distinguishes itself from related works.

references: OurÂ HyFL framework is based on a three-layer
Additional layers can be easily incorporated depending on the scale of deployment.
architecture and extends the established hierarchicalÂ FLÂ (HFL) paradigmÂ

.
InÂ HFL, clients are initially organized into clusters, and their local models are aggregated at cluster level;
these cluster-level models are then further aggregated globally, resulting in an additional layer of aggregation.
We adopt the hierarchical approach inÂ HyFL for two main reasons: firstly, to efficiently realize our distinct model training approach for global model privacy, and secondly, to facilitate large-scale deployments across heterogeneous clients. However, there is one key difference: at the cluster level, HyFL does not perform aggregation of models but private training on collective client data. This differs from both traditional and hierarchicalÂ FL since the data is not kept solely on the client devices. Nevertheless, HyFL ensures that the data remains within the trusted domain of the client, allowing for accurate modeling of trust relationships between clients in real-world situations, such as trust among members of the same region or countryÂ
. Furthermore, this type of hierarchy is ubiquitous in real-world scenarios such asÂ P2P gaming, organizations, and network infrastructuresÂ

We provide details for each layer inÂ HyFL next.
We focus on the sequence of operations performed by the entities in our architectureÂ (cf.Â Fig.Â
iterations while considering necessaryÂ MPC protocols and setup requirements. Since we have a generic design, we design our framework in the
-hybrid model with the MPC protocols abstracted, and their specifics are given inÂ Tab.Â

.
The notations used inÂ HyFL are listed inÂ Tab.Â

However, HyFL is not bound to any specificÂ MPC setting and could be instantiated using anyÂ MPC protocol.

references: One notable feature of ourÂ HyFL architectureÂ (cf.Â Fig.Â
) is its capability to encompass multiple existing FL frameworks, as shown inÂ Tab.Â
. This abstraction not only simplifies comparisons but also facilitates advanced hybrid designs, including the integration of differential privacy.
StandardÂ FL with a single aggregatorÂ (
is a variant ofÂ HyFL, where eachÂ LayerÂ III clusterÂ
consists of only one client that also serves as theÂ MPC cluster serverÂ

inÂ LayerÂ II.
Thus, it is sufficient to conductÂ ML training without privacy concerns and then send the results to a single global serverÂ

inÂ LayerÂ I for aggregation.
The case of distributed aggregatorsÂ (
follows similarly, except secure aggregation being performed atÂ LayerÂ I with multipleÂ (

) global servers.
Finally, existing hierarchicalÂ FL schemesÂ
share a similar three-layer architecture withÂ HyFL, but have a single server at both the global and cluster levelÂ (
Advanced hybrid designs inÂ HyFL could incorporate data from

clients, such as trusted consortium members, without hiding the global model. The client can train the model locally and share the gradients with aggregation servers.
Another hybrid could include a collaborative training model like SafeNetÂ

, which resists poisoning attacks to some extent. SafeNet defines the global model as an ensemble of verified models, with the majority prediction determining the final output. This setup can replace an MPC cluster and its associated clients in HyFL. The ensemble models can be aggregated or subjected to MPC-based clusteringÂ

to obtain a single model. The remaining process follows the HyFL architecture, replacing operations in SafeNet on the plain model with corresponding MPC counterparts. Additionally, the training in the MPC clusters, resilient to poisoning attacks, can be categorized as
. The global servers can use a simple or mildly robust aggregation scheme to incorporate updates from these clusters, decreasing the likelihood of error propagation to higher layers.

references: We evaluate the run-time and communication overhead of ourÂ FLTrust andÂ TM implementation inÂ CrypTen inÂ Tab.Â

.
The run-time overhead for both robust aggregation schemes compared toÂ FedAvg is four to five orders of magnitude.
Also, FLTrust requiresÂ 5

more run-time and communication thanÂ TM.
Given that both produce fairly similar results when applied toÂ HyFL, the overhead forÂ FLTrust seems not warranted.

references: , we compare the effectiveness of ourÂ TM variant to the originalÂ TMÂ

for three sample sizesÂ (10, 100, andÂ 1000).
It turns out that our heuristic approach barely reduces the effectiveness, even with aggressive parameters.
In fact, in the focused setting, theÂ TM variant outperforms the original.
This is because our variant completely excludes gradient updates ofÂ (poisoned) outliers, whereas in regular trimmed mean, those poisoned updates might still be considered for some coordinates. Results for all other settings are presented inÂ App.Â

, we also provide run-times and communication results for our optimizations.
Compared to the original withÂ 1021.59MB of communication, we can see an improvement by two orders of magnitude with a communication ofÂ 11.90MB for the variant withÂ 100 random samples.
However, we see a higher and fairly stable run-time across all three examined variants.
This is because the algorithm for determining the overall ranking of outliers across coordinates increases the number ofÂ MPC communication rounds compared to the original.
In the studied inter-continentalÂ WAN setting, this has severe impact but does not correspond to actual compute time.

Overall, ifÂ HyFL is combined with a robust aggregation scheme, ourÂ TM variant offers an excellent trade-off between accuracy andÂ MPC overhead compared to significantly more expensiveÂ FLTrust and the originalÂ TM.

Values 50 128 0.05 0.9 0.0005
references: In data-poisoning attacks, malicious clients can perform arbitrary manipulations to the training data. State-of-the-art attacks are based on label flipping, where clients keep the legitimate training samples, yet exchange the associated labels according to different strategies.

We implement four label-flipping attacks in HyFL, and the details are presented next. In the attack scenario, we assume a single attacker controlling all malicious clients, coordinating their actions. Only one attack occurs at a time, and if multiple clients have the same data sample, their poisoned labels will be the same. The assumption is that each malicious client poisons all its data samples to maximize the attackâ€™s impact. The data is poisoned once and the labels remain constant throughout the modelâ€™s training.
): Each poisoned sample is assigned a random class label, i.e., forÂ
): Uses a fixed permutation to determine the new label for each poisoned sample, given by the equation

): Employs a surrogate model to flip the labels for each sample. In our implementation, we aggregate the data from all malicious clients and utilize it to train a model with the same architecture as the one used in HyFL training. Once trained, this model is utilized for inference and the labels are assigned to the least probable output determined by the surrogate model. The termÂ

is used because the labels rely on the trained model, and by altering the training configuration, the poisoned labels will be modified accordingly. The exact training settings of the surrogate model are given inÂ Tab.Â
): Simply flips all labels from a source class to a target class. In HyFL, we always set the source class asÂ 0 and the target class asÂ 1.

Tab.Â

shows the settings that affect the training by the clients andÂ MPC clusters respectively.
We considerÂ 1000 clients overall from whichÂ 100 are randomly sampled during each training iteration.
In theÂ FL setting, all sampled clients provide their computed update directly to the aggregation server.
In theÂ HyFL setting, each of theÂ 10Â MPC clusters hasÂ 100 associated clients from which each samplesÂ 10 clients at random.
Each client hasÂ 200 data points assigned to it at random with duplicates allowed between clients.
To allow for a fair comparison betweenÂ FL andÂ HyFL, we scale the learning rate fromÂ 0.005 for theÂ FL setting toÂ 0.05 for theÂ HyFL setting.
Each client andÂ MPC cluster performsÂ 5 local training epochs with either a batch size ofÂ 8 orÂ 80, respectively, following the recommendation ofÂ

shows the hyper parameters used by the aggregation server.
The trimmed mean thresholdÂ

has been chosen such that it can exclude all malicious updates on either side in theÂ FL setting.
The worst-case scenario we consider is aÂ 0.2 poison rate, which is equivalent to approximatelyÂ 20 malicious clients selected per round.
In theÂ HyFL setting, the cluster-focused setting is the strongest adversarial setting and we therefore appropriately scaleÂ

.
For the trimmed mean variant, we exclude complete updates based on how often they were detected as outliers and therefore need to doubleÂ
to later aggregate the same number of parameters per coordinate.

FLTrust uses a root data set to calculate the server model.
To be most effective, the server model must be similar to the benign models and therefore the root dataset must be representative for the whole dataset.
Therefore, we sampleÂ (like for all clients)Â 200 data points for that dataset.
